I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support Henan 
province in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) to reform its budget expenditure management 
system. The TA will have two components that will study the development program expenditure 
streams for (i) the traditional development program for expenditure standards, and (ii) the 
emerging development program, using agricultural insurance as a case study. This will help the 
provincial government formulate development program expenditure standards to more efficiently 
and effectively allocate budget resources with the aim of strengthening budget expenditure 
management.  
 
2.  The Government of the PRC requested a TA from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
Support to Public and Finance Sector Reform in Henan Province.1 The TA is included in ADB’s 
country operations business plan for the PRC, 2017–2019.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Henan province is in the central region of the PRC and is the country’s most populous 
province, with over 94 million inhabitants, or about 7% of the national population. The per capita 
income in Henan is below the national average and the economy is dominated by agriculture, 
mining, and traditional manufacturing, with a relatively small services sector. In 2016, Henan’s 
general revenue was $46.7 billion and its general expenditure was $110.5 billion. Approximately 
70% of expenditure is on various development programs, including social development programs 
and infrastructure investment projects, the costs of which vary tremendously by both year and 
program. About 30% of expenditure is for government operational costs, which are relatively 
constant. 
 
4.  The  large  fiscal  gap  between  revenue  and  expenditure  and  the  complexity  in  cost 
estimation, standardization, and budgeting means the province faces tremendous fiscal pressure 
each year, with expectation and reliance on the downward intergovernment transfer payment from 
the central government. There is a significant need for the Henan Provincial Finance Department 
(HPFD) to reduce its reliance on the central government and reform its budget management 
system to develop program expenditure standards that could help estimate and justify budget 
allocations. Without practical expenditure standards, budget preparation and approval rely heavily 
on  the  bargaining  power  between  spending  units  and  budget  authority,  instead  of  solid 
computation of cost items. This compromises budget accuracy and preciseness. A budget that is 
less  accurate  requires  frequent  adjustments  during  execution,  which  often  delays  the 
implementation of development programs and undermines their expected outcomes, reducing the 
effectiveness and efficiency of budgetary expenditure management.  
 
5.  Henan  was  selected  by  MOF  as  a  pilot  province  to  develop  program  expenditure 
standards in 2016. In line with MOF’s pilot guidance, HPFD divides the development programs 
into traditional development programs and emerging or innovative development programs. The 
traditional  development  programs,  e.g.,  office  building  construction  and  maintenance, 
demographic census, and information and communication technology programs, have adequate 
reference databases, computable cost items, clear engineering frameworks, practical procedures, 
and well-defined outputs and outcomes. These advantages help put the traditional development

programs in a good position to set up program expenditure standards, and this then allows the 
programs to be costed and budgeted in line with these preset expenditure standards.  
 
6.  HPFD plans to develop consistent and comparable expenditure standards for all the 
traditional  development  programs.  In  line  with  this  pilot  program,  three  types  of  program 
expenditure standards will be developed: (i) common-use expenditure standards, which apply to 
budgeting of similar programs across provincial government agencies; (ii) department-specific 
expenditure standards, which apply to budgeting of similar programs in various subunits within a 
provincial department; and (iii) program-specific expenditure standards, which only apply to 
programs that have special technical requirements and cost factors. At the same time, a new 
classification of program expenditures will be introduced.  HPFD will work together with all 
provincial departments to develop the common-use program expenditure standards, and assist 
each provincial department to develop department-specific expenditure standards and program-
specific expenditure standards.3  
 
7.  The emerging development programs involve complicated policy or institutional reforms, 
and  have  inadequate  reference  databases,  unclear  frameworks,  and  unfixed  cost  items. 
Agricultural  insurance  is  an  emerging  development  program,  seen  as  an  important  risk 
management tool for farmers. Henan is an important agriculture province, being a core grain 
producer for the PRC, which faces major risks of price volatility,4 production failure, and along the 
whole  agribusiness  value  chain (post-harvest  storage  and  logistics),  which  has  resulted  in 
economic losses, contributes to the government’s fiscal burden, and directly impacts national food 
security.5 With a high proportion of rural households dependent on publicly provided assistance, 
risk management  strategies  and measures  are  important to  reduce  this  burden, for  which 
insurance (an emerging industry in the PRC) has increasing importance. 
 
8.  The PRC embarked on a major program under the Eleventh Five-Year Plan to promote 
agricultural insurance through a massive injection of premium subsidies to promote decentralized 
agricultural insurance.6 The number of policies increased significantly and, in 2016, agricultural 
insurance premiums reached $6.2 billion, making it the second largest agricultural insurance 
market in the world after the United States.7 Existing agricultural insurance products focus on 
production, with multi-peril crop insurance (MPCI) and high-value livestock insurance, such as for 
breeding sows and dairy cows. The focus in Henan province has been on cropping for grain 
production and high value livestock. Although a growing market, the available insurance is narrow 
and does not provide adequate multilevel risk management due to the supply and demand 
mismatch  which  does  not  meet  the  demands  of  modern  agriculture.  A  lack  of  consumer 
awareness about insurance and its benefits also inhibits uptake of available insurance products. 
The cost effectiveness for insurance companies, to develop and offer MPCI products is extremely 
challenging, is associated with high administrative costs when dealing with many small holder 
farmers and a lesser number of enterprises and cooperatives, lack of data quality and information 
transparency and poor actuarial performance. In addition, access to insurance is not linked to

targeted insurance products, more efficient delivery channels, and to refocus the use of traditional 
subsidies.  
 
9.  In addition to insurance, additional risk management solutions to avoid, mitigate, or 
transfer risks, which combine technical and financial tools and approaches should be applied. The 
enabling  environment  and  specific  government  policies  to  promote  risk  mitigation  through 
agricultural insurance, coupled with access to finance and sound risk management, can contribute 
to (i) stabilizing agricultural production and farm incomes in times of major production loss and (ii) 
modernizing agriculture through its ability to leverage access to credit, thereby enabling farmers 
to purchase production-enhancing technology.   
 
10.  Developing expenditure standards to improve budget preparation as well as improving 
utilization of available fiscal resources, such as subsidies, will help HPFD to enhance fiscal 
management. This will ensure there is adequate financing for its development programs and 
contribute to achieving their development objectives.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: public sector management improved.9 The TA 
will have the following outcome: program budget accuracy and preciseness improved.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Budgetary expenditure standards for selected development programs 
formulated. This output will assist HPFD in developing a budgetary expenditure standard system 
for  traditional  development  programs  with  the  aim  of  strengthening  budgetary  program 
expenditure  management.  Specifically,  the  subproject  aims  to  (i)  summarize  domestic  and 
international best practices in setting up program expenditure standards, (ii) analyze the major 
technical challenges and institutional obstacles that need to be addressed, (iii) construct a general 
framework for setting up a program expenditure standard system, (iv) develop procedures and 
methods for program costing, (v) formulate expenditure standards for selected programs, (vi) 
provide policy recommendations for improving program expenditure standards and draw up an 
action  plan  to  complete  the  program  expenditure  standard  system,  and  (vii)  disseminate 
knowledge products. 
 
13.  Output  2:  Agricultural  insurance  services  for  modern  agriculture  development 
prepared. As Henan is an agricultural province, significant fiscal outlay has been allocated for 
agriculture, forestry, and water resources. This output will assist HPFD to review its budget 
expenditure under the emerging development program category for agricultural insurance so it 
can apply a new approach to reviewing and assessing budget allocation and demand. Specifically, 
the subproject aims to (i) assess agricultural supply chain (inputs, services, production, post-
harvest, processing, logistics) risks and risk management strategies; (ii) review the current 
subsidy mechanism, financing streams, and effectiveness, and propose improved approaches to

financing insurance; (iii) conduct agricultural insurance industry diagnostic review, including 
potential use of high-level technology in agricultural insurance;11 (iv) disseminate information and 
raise awareness through a conference; (v) propose improved agricultural insurance solutions, 
other risk mitigation strategies, investment and an enabling policy environment; (vi) summarize 
domestic and international best practices; and (vii) build knowledge and institutional capacity for 
risk  management.  The  agricultural  insurance  case  study  will  be  used  as  a  demonstration 
approach to improving development program efficiency and effectiveness. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.62 million, of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) to finance component 
1,  and  $750,000  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Financial  Sector  Development 
Partnership Special Fund12 (FSDPSF) to finance component 2.13 The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
facilities, domestic transportation, provision of available relevant government data and studies for 
the  TA  consultants’  use,  provision  of  meeting  rooms,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The 
government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project.

17.  Cofinancier requirements. Upon funding approval, the Environment, Natural Resources 
and Agriculture Division of ADB’s East Asia Department will submit semiannual progress reports 
to  the  FSDPSF fund manager  every  31 July  and  31  January,  and  additional  updates (as 
necessary) on project implementation. For major changes in project scope, duration, or funding 
arrangement, the Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division should circulate draft 
memos to the FSDPSF fund manager for initial assessment before an interdepartmental review 
by ADB’s Operations Services and Financial Management Department, Controller’s Department, 
Office of the General Counsel, and Office of Cofinancing Operations. 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consulting firms and individual consultants in 
accordance with ADB Procurement  Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the 
associated  project  administration  instructions  and  TA  staff  instructions  using  the  simplified 
technical proposal, and quality- and cost-based selection method and individual consultant 
selection.14 The quality–cost ratio will be 90:10 because of the high technical complexity of the 
consulting assignment. In line with the action plan for ADB’s Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: 
Action Plan,15 an output-based contract may be offered. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed 
following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The consultants will submit progress reports, which will be reviewed by ADB and the 
government. 
 
19.  Output 1 of the TA will require 53 person-months of consulting services (3 person-months 
of  international  and  50  person-months  of  national  inputs).  An  international  budgeting  and 
expenditure management specialist will be recruited as an individual consultant, and a consulting 
firm will be recruited to provide national specialists. The consulting firm team will consist of seven 
national specialists: a program expenditure management specialist, who will be the team leader; 
a budget management specialist as deputy team leader; and budget specialists for education, 
health, environmental protection, industrial development, and science and technology. Output 2 
of  the  TA  will  require  27.5  person-months  of  consulting  services  (6.5  person-months  of 
international and 21.0 person-months of national inputs). An international agricultural insurance 
specialist  and  an  international  agriculture  risk  management  specialist  will  be  recruited  as 
individual consultants and a firm will be recruited to provide national specialists. The consulting 
firm team will consist of five national specialists: an agriculture specialist, who will be the team 
leader; an institutional and policy specialist; a public financial management specialist; an actuary; 
and an insurance specialist. Resource persons may be recruited to review the consultants’ 
outputs and share knowledge during workshops in accordance with ADB’s guidelines on recruiting 
and administering resource persons. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Support to Public Finance and Finance 
Sector Reform in Henan Province, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
